title: How to Connect OpenClaw to Telegram: Complete Setup Guide
description: Step-by-step guide to connecting OpenClaw to Telegram. Create a bot, configure webhooks, and run your AI assistant in any Telegram chat.

setupSteps.title: Create a Telegram Bot via BotFather
setupSteps.content:
Open Telegram and search for @BotFather. Send /newbot and follow the prompts to name your bot. BotFather will give you a bot token ‚Äî a long string like 7123456789:AAHx.... Save this token securely; you'll need it in the next step.

Optionally, send /setdescription and /setabouttext to customize how your bot appears to users.

setupSteps.title: Configure OpenClaw's Telegram Channel
setupSteps.content:
In your OpenClaw config file (openclaw.json), add the Telegram channel:

{
  "channels": {
    "telegram": {
      "botToken": "YOUR_BOT_TOKEN_HERE",
      "allowedUsers": ["your_telegram_user_id"],
      "polling": true
    }
  }
}

Set polling: true for simple setups (no public URL needed). For production, use webhooks with a public HTTPS endpoint instead.

setupSteps.title: Set Up Webhooks (Production)
setupSteps.content:
For a production setup, configure a webhook so Telegram pushes messages to your server instead of OpenClaw polling for them:

openclaw gateway config set telegram.webhook.url https://your-domain.com/telegram/webhook
openclaw gateway restart

You'll need a valid SSL certificate. If you're running on a VPS with Nginx, use Let's Encrypt for free certificates.

setupSteps.title: Start OpenClaw and Test
setupSteps.content:
Start (or restart) OpenClaw:

openclaw gateway start

Open your bot in Telegram and send a message. Your OpenClaw instance should respond. If it doesn't, check openclaw gateway status for errors.

useCases: Personal AI assistant accessible from your phone anywhere
Group chat bot that answers team questions and runs automations
Customer support bot for Telegram-based communities
Automated notifications ‚Äî server alerts, calendar reminders, sales updates
platformNotes:
Telegram is one of the most popular channels for OpenClaw because of its excellent bot API. Key advantages:

  • No approval process ‚Äî create a bot instantly via BotFather
  • Rich media support ‚Äî send images, files, buttons, and inline keyboards
  • Group chat support ‚Äî add your bot to any group
  • Free and unlimited ‚Äî no per-message costs from Telegram

Telegram's Bot API supports both long polling and webhooks. Polling is easier to set up (no public URL required), while webhooks are more efficient for production use.
requirements: A Telegram account
A bot token from @BotFather
OpenClaw installed on a VPS or local machine
A public HTTPS endpoint (for webhooks only)

title: How to Connect OpenClaw to Slack: Complete Setup Guide
description: Step-by-step guide to connecting OpenClaw to Slack. Create a Slack app, configure OAuth, and run your AI assistant in any Slack workspace.

setupSteps.title: Create a Slack App
setupSteps.content:
Go to api.slack.com/apps and click Create New App. Choose "From scratch" and give it a name (e.g., "OpenClaw"). Select your workspace.

Under OAuth & Permissions, add these bot token scopes:

  • chat:write ‚Äî send messages
  • channels:history ‚Äî read channel messages
  • channels:read ‚Äî list channels
  • im:history ‚Äî read DMs
  • im:write ‚Äî send DMs
  • reactions:write ‚Äî add emoji reactions
  • users:read ‚Äî look up user info

setupSteps.title: Install the App and Get Tokens
setupSteps.content:
Click Install to Workspace and authorize. You'll get two important values:

  • Bot User OAuth Token (starts with xoxb-)
  • App-Level Token ‚Äî create one under Basic Information ‚Üí App-Level Tokens with the connections:write scope (starts with xapp-)

Enable Socket Mode under Settings ‚Äî this lets OpenClaw connect without a public URL.

setupSteps.title: Configure OpenClaw
setupSteps.content:
Add the Slack channel to your OpenClaw config:

{
  "channels": {
    "slack": {
      "botToken": "xoxb-YOUR-BOT-TOKEN",
      "appToken": "xapp-YOUR-APP-TOKEN",
      "signingSecret": "YOUR_SIGNING_SECRET"
    }
  }
}

The signing secret is found under Basic Information in your Slack app settings.

setupSteps.title: Enable Event Subscriptions
setupSteps.content:
Under Event Subscriptions, subscribe to these bot events:

  • message.channels ‚Äî messages in public channels
  • message.im ‚Äî direct messages
  • app_mention ‚Äî when someone @mentions your bot

With Socket Mode enabled, you don't need a request URL. Start OpenClaw and it connects automatically:

openclaw gateway start

useCases: Team AI assistant that answers questions in any channel
Automated standup reports and meeting summaries
Sales and CRM notifications piped into Slack channels
Internal knowledge base ‚Äî ask your bot instead of searching docs
platformNotes:
Slack is the most feature-rich integration for OpenClaw in a business context. Key advantages:

  • Socket Mode ‚Äî no public URL needed, works behind firewalls
  • Thread support ‚Äî bot replies stay organized in threads
  • Rich formatting ‚Äî markdown, code blocks, buttons, modals
  • Workspace-wide access ‚Äî one bot serves your entire team

Slack's API has rate limits (roughly 1 message per second per channel). OpenClaw handles this automatically with built-in queuing.
requirements: A Slack workspace (free or paid)
Admin permissions to install apps
OpenClaw installed on a VPS or local machine
Bot and app-level tokens from Slack

title: How to Connect OpenClaw to WhatsApp: Complete Setup Guide
description: Step-by-step guide to connecting OpenClaw to WhatsApp. Set up the WhatsApp Business API or use a bridge to run your AI assistant on WhatsApp.

setupSteps.title: Choose Your WhatsApp Integration Method
setupSteps.content:
There are two main ways to connect OpenClaw to WhatsApp:

  • WhatsApp Business API (official) ‚Äî requires a Meta Business account and verification. Best for businesses that need reliability and compliance.
  • WhatsApp Web bridge (unofficial) ‚Äî uses libraries like whatsapp-web.js or Baileys to connect via the WhatsApp Web protocol. Easier to set up but less stable.

For most users, the official Business API is recommended. The bridge approach works for personal/experimental use.

setupSteps.title: Set Up WhatsApp Business API
setupSteps.content:
Go to developers.facebook.com and create a new app of type "Business". Add the WhatsApp product. You'll get:

  • A Phone Number ID
  • A WhatsApp Business Account ID
  • A temporary access token (generate a permanent one via System Users)

Set up a webhook URL where Meta will send incoming messages. You'll need a public HTTPS endpoint.

setupSteps.title: Configure OpenClaw for WhatsApp
setupSteps.content:
Add the WhatsApp channel to your config:

{
  "channels": {
    "whatsapp": {
      "provider": "business-api",
      "phoneNumberId": "YOUR_PHONE_NUMBER_ID",
      "accessToken": "YOUR_PERMANENT_TOKEN",
      "verifyToken": "YOUR_WEBHOOK_VERIFY_TOKEN",
      "webhookPath": "/whatsapp/webhook"
    }
  }
}

The verifyToken is a string you choose ‚Äî Meta uses it to verify your webhook endpoint.

setupSteps.title: Test and Go Live
setupSteps.content:
Start OpenClaw and send a test message to your WhatsApp Business number:

openclaw gateway start

Note: With the Business API, you can only respond to messages within a 24-hour window unless you use approved message templates. Set up templates in the Meta Business dashboard for proactive outreach.

useCases: Customer support on WhatsApp ‚Äî the world's most popular messaging app
Personal AI assistant you can text from anywhere
Automated appointment reminders and confirmations
E-commerce order updates and tracking notifications
platformNotes:
WhatsApp has over 2 billion users worldwide, making it the largest messaging platform. Key considerations:

  • 24-hour messaging window ‚Äî you can only reply within 24 hours of the customer's last message (Business API)
  • Message templates ‚Äî required for sending messages outside the 24-hour window; must be pre-approved by Meta
  • End-to-end encryption ‚Äî WhatsApp messages are encrypted, but Business API messages are decrypted at Meta's servers
  • Cost ‚Äî Meta charges per conversation (pricing varies by country, starting around $0.005‚Äì$0.08 per conversation)
requirements: A Meta Business account (verified)
A phone number dedicated to WhatsApp Business
OpenClaw installed on a VPS with a public HTTPS endpoint
An SSL certificate for webhook verification

title: How to Connect OpenClaw to Discord: Complete Setup Guide
description: Step-by-step guide to connecting OpenClaw to Discord. Create a bot, set permissions, and run your AI assistant in any Discord server.

setupSteps.title: Create a Discord Application and Bot
setupSteps.content:
Go to the Discord Developer Portal and click New Application. Name it (e.g., "OpenClaw") and go to the Bot tab.

Click Add Bot, then:

  • Copy the bot token ‚Äî you'll need this for OpenClaw
  • Enable Message Content Intent under Privileged Gateway Intents (required to read message content)
  • Enable Server Members Intent if you want user info

setupSteps.title: Invite the Bot to Your Server
setupSteps.content:
Go to OAuth2 ‚Üí URL Generator. Select these scopes:

  • bot
  • applications.commands

Under Bot Permissions, select:

  • Send Messages, Read Message History, Add Reactions, Embed Links, Attach Files, Use Slash Commands

Copy the generated URL and open it in your browser. Select your server and authorize the bot.

setupSteps.title: Configure OpenClaw
setupSteps.content:
Add Discord to your OpenClaw config:

{
  "channels": {
    "discord": {
      "botToken": "YOUR_DISCORD_BOT_TOKEN",
      "allowedGuilds": ["YOUR_SERVER_ID"],
      "allowedChannels": ["CHANNEL_ID_1", "CHANNEL_ID_2"]
    }
  }
}

To get server and channel IDs: enable Developer Mode in Discord settings (User Settings ‚Üí Advanced ‚Üí Developer Mode), then right-click on servers/channels to copy their IDs.

setupSteps.title: Start and Test
setupSteps.content:
Start OpenClaw:

openclaw gateway start

Go to a channel where your bot has access and send a message mentioning it (e.g., @OpenClaw what's the weather?). The bot should respond in the channel.

You can also DM the bot directly for private conversations.

useCases: Community management bot for Discord servers
AI-powered moderation assistant
Gaming community helper ‚Äî look up stats, schedules, and info
Team collaboration bot for private Discord servers
platformNotes:
Discord is hugely popular for communities and increasingly for business teams. Key features for OpenClaw:

  • No public URL needed ‚Äî Discord uses a WebSocket gateway, so your bot connects outbound
  • Thread support ‚Äî keep conversations organized
  • Slash commands ‚Äî register custom /commands for structured interactions
  • Rich embeds ‚Äî beautiful formatted messages with colors, images, and fields
  • Free ‚Äî no per-message costs from Discord

Note: Discord requires the Message Content Intent for bots in 100+ servers. For private/small servers, it's automatically available.
requirements: A Discord account
A server where you have admin/manage permissions
OpenClaw installed on a VPS or local machine
Bot token from the Discord Developer Portal

title: How to Connect OpenClaw to Signal: Complete Setup Guide
description: Step-by-step guide to connecting OpenClaw to Signal. Use signal-cli or the Signal API to run a privacy-focused AI assistant.

setupSteps.title: Install signal-cli
setupSteps.content:
Signal doesn't offer an official bot API, so we use signal-cli, an open-source command-line client. Install it on your server:

wget https://github.com/AsamK/signal-cli/releases/latest/download/signal-cli-Linux.tar.gz
tar xf signal-cli-Linux.tar.gz
sudo mv signal-cli-*/bin/signal-cli /usr/local/bin/
sudo mv signal-cli-*/lib /usr/local/lib/signal-cli

Verify installation: signal-cli --version

setupSteps.title: Register a Phone Number with Signal
setupSteps.content:
You need a dedicated phone number for your bot. Register it with Signal:

signal-cli -u +1YOUR_PHONE_NUMBER register
signal-cli -u +1YOUR_PHONE_NUMBER verify CODE_FROM_SMS

Consider using a VoIP number or a cheap prepaid SIM dedicated to your bot. The number will appear as a regular Signal contact to other users.

setupSteps.title: Run signal-cli in Daemon Mode
setupSteps.content:
Start signal-cli as a JSON-RPC daemon so OpenClaw can communicate with it:

signal-cli -u +1YOUR_PHONE_NUMBER daemon --socket /tmp/signal-cli.sock

For production, set this up as a systemd service so it starts automatically.

setupSteps.title: Configure OpenClaw
setupSteps.content:
Add Signal to your OpenClaw config:

{
  "channels": {
    "signal": {
      "provider": "signal-cli",
      "socket": "/tmp/signal-cli.sock",
      "phoneNumber": "+1YOUR_PHONE_NUMBER",
      "allowedNumbers": ["+1TRUSTED_NUMBER"]
    }
  }
}

The allowedNumbers field restricts who can interact with your bot. Important for security since anyone with the number could message it.

useCases: Privacy-focused personal AI assistant
Secure team communication with AI capabilities
Encrypted notifications for sensitive alerts (security, finance)
Whistleblower or journalist support tool with end-to-end encryption
platformNotes:
Signal is the gold standard for private messaging. Connecting OpenClaw to Signal gives you an AI assistant with true end-to-end encryption. Key considerations:

  • No official bot API ‚Äî relies on signal-cli, which is community-maintained
  • End-to-end encrypted ‚Äî messages are encrypted even from your server (signal-cli decrypts locally)
  • Requires a real phone number ‚Äî no way around this
  • Group chat support ‚Äî signal-cli can send and receive in Signal groups
  • Less stable than official APIs ‚Äî Signal protocol updates can temporarily break signal-cli
requirements: A dedicated phone number for Signal registration
signal-cli installed on your server
Java 21+ runtime (required by signal-cli)
OpenClaw installed on a VPS

title: How to Connect OpenClaw to Google Chat: Complete Setup Guide
description: Step-by-step guide to connecting OpenClaw to Google Chat. Create a Google Chat app and run your AI assistant in Google Workspace.

setupSteps.title: Create a Google Cloud Project
setupSteps.content:
Go to the Google Cloud Console and create a new project (or use an existing one). Enable the Google Chat API from the API Library.

Navigate to APIs & Services ‚Üí Credentials and create a Service Account. Download the JSON key file ‚Äî you'll need it for OpenClaw.

setupSteps.title: Configure the Google Chat App
setupSteps.content:
In the Google Cloud Console, go to Google Chat API ‚Üí Configuration and set up your app:

  • App name: OpenClaw
  • Avatar URL: your bot's avatar
  • Description: AI assistant powered by OpenClaw
  • Functionality: Enable "Receive 1:1 messages" and "Join spaces and group conversations"
  • Connection settings: Choose "HTTP endpoint URL" and enter your server's webhook URL

setupSteps.title: Configure OpenClaw
setupSteps.content:
Add Google Chat to your OpenClaw config:

{
  "channels": {
    "google-chat": {
      "serviceAccountKey": "/path/to/service-account-key.json",
      "webhookPath": "/google-chat/webhook"
    }
  }
}

Make sure your server is accessible over HTTPS ‚Äî Google Chat requires a verified endpoint.

setupSteps.title: Deploy and Test
setupSteps.content:
Start OpenClaw and ensure your webhook endpoint is reachable:

openclaw gateway start

In Google Chat, search for your app by name and start a direct message. Your bot should respond to messages. You can also add it to Google Chat spaces (group conversations).

Note: Google Chat apps are only available in Google Workspace organizations ‚Äî not personal Gmail accounts.

useCases: Enterprise AI assistant integrated with Google Workspace
Automated reporting in Google Chat spaces
IT helpdesk bot for Google Workspace organizations
Meeting prep and follow-up automation tied to Google Calendar
platformNotes:
Google Chat is the default messaging platform for Google Workspace (formerly G Suite) organizations. Key details:

  • Workspace only ‚Äî Google Chat apps only work within Google Workspace organizations, not personal Gmail
  • Card-based UI ‚Äî supports rich interactive cards with buttons, forms, and images
  • Google integration ‚Äî natively connected to Calendar, Drive, Meet, and other Workspace tools
  • Admin approval may be required ‚Äî your Workspace admin might need to allowlist the app
requirements: A Google Workspace organization (not personal Gmail)
Google Cloud project with Chat API enabled
A service account with proper permissions
OpenClaw installed on a server with a public HTTPS endpoint

title: How to Connect OpenClaw to iMessage: Complete Setup Guide
description: Step-by-step guide to connecting OpenClaw to iMessage. Use a Mac-based bridge to run your AI assistant through Apple Messages.

setupSteps.title: Understand the Limitations
setupSteps.content:
Apple doesn't offer a public iMessage API. Connecting OpenClaw to iMessage requires a Mac that stays online running a bridge application. This Mac acts as the relay between iMessage and your OpenClaw instance.

The most reliable approach uses BlueBubbles or Beeper as the bridge layer. BlueBubbles is open-source and runs on your own Mac.

setupSteps.title: Set Up BlueBubbles on a Mac
setupSteps.content:
Download BlueBubbles and install it on a Mac that will stay online (a Mac Mini is ideal for this). During setup:

  • Sign in with your Apple ID
  • Enable the BlueBubbles Private API (requires disabling SIP ‚Äî follow their guide carefully)
  • Configure the server to use a Firebase Cloud Messaging project for notifications
  • Note your server URL and password

setupSteps.title: Configure OpenClaw to Use the Bridge
setupSteps.content:
OpenClaw connects to BlueBubbles via its REST API:

{
  "channels": {
    "imessage": {
      "provider": "bluebubbles",
      "serverUrl": "https://your-bluebubbles-server:1234",
      "password": "YOUR_BLUEBUBBLES_PASSWORD",
      "allowedContacts": ["+1YOUR_NUMBER"]
    }
  }
}

The allowedContacts list is crucial ‚Äî without it, anyone who texts your Apple ID gets an AI response.

setupSteps.title: Start and Test
setupSteps.content:
Make sure BlueBubbles is running on your Mac, then start OpenClaw:

openclaw gateway start

Send an iMessage to the Apple ID signed into BlueBubbles. OpenClaw should receive it and reply as an iMessage. Replies appear as blue bubbles to the sender.

useCases: AI assistant for iPhone users who live in the Apple ecosystem
Respond to personal messages when you're busy
Automated appointment scheduling via iMessage
Smart auto-replies with context awareness
platformNotes:
iMessage is the default messaging platform for Apple users. Integrating with it is non-trivial but valuable if your users are in the Apple ecosystem. Key considerations:

  • Requires a Mac ‚Äî there's no way around this; Apple locks iMessage to their hardware
  • Blue bubbles ‚Äî replies appear as genuine iMessages, not SMS
  • Rich features ‚Äî supports images, reactions (tapbacks), group chats, and read receipts
  • Stability concerns ‚Äî Apple occasionally changes internal APIs, which can break bridges
  • Privacy ‚Äî messages pass through your own Mac; no third-party servers see the content
requirements: A Mac (Mini recommended) that stays powered on 24/7
An Apple ID signed into Messages
BlueBubbles or similar bridge software
OpenClaw installed on a VPS or the same Mac

title: How to Connect OpenClaw to IRC: Complete Setup Guide
description: Step-by-step guide to connecting OpenClaw to IRC. Connect your AI assistant to any IRC network and channel.

setupSteps.title: Choose Your IRC Network
setupSteps.content:
OpenClaw can connect to any IRC network. Popular choices in 2026:

  • Libera.Chat ‚Äî the spiritual successor to Freenode, home of most open-source projects
  • OFTC ‚Äî used by Debian and other infrastructure projects
  • Your company's private IRC server

Register a nickname for your bot on your chosen network. On Libera.Chat:

/msg NickServ REGISTER password email@example.com

setupSteps.title: Configure OpenClaw for IRC
setupSteps.content:
Add IRC to your OpenClaw config:

{
  "channels": {
    "irc": {
      "server": "irc.libera.chat",
      "port": 6697,
      "ssl": true,
      "nick": "OpenClawBot",
      "password": "YOUR_NICKSERV_PASSWORD",
      "channels": ["#your-channel"],
      "allowedNicks": ["yournick"]
    }
  }
}

Always use port 6697 with ssl: true for encrypted connections.

setupSteps.title: Start and Join Channels
setupSteps.content:
Start OpenClaw:

openclaw gateway start

The bot will connect to the IRC server, authenticate with NickServ, and join the configured channels. Users can interact by mentioning the bot's nick or sending it a private message.

useCases: AI assistant for open-source project channels
Automated documentation lookup in dev channels
Log aggregation and alerting via IRC
Old-school chat bot with modern AI capabilities
platformNotes:
IRC has been around since 1988 and is still used heavily in open-source and infrastructure communities. Key features:

  • No approval process ‚Äî connect to any public network instantly
  • Lightweight protocol ‚Äî minimal resource usage
  • No rate limits ‚Äî though some networks throttle excessive messaging
  • Plain text ‚Äî no rich formatting, but code-friendly
  • Multiple networks ‚Äî OpenClaw can connect to several IRC networks simultaneously
requirements: An IRC network to connect to
A registered nickname (recommended)
OpenClaw installed on a VPS or local machine

title: How to Connect OpenClaw to Email: Complete Setup Guide
description: Step-by-step guide to connecting OpenClaw to Email via IMAP/SMTP. Build an AI assistant that reads, drafts, and sends emails.

setupSteps.title: Set Up an Email Account for Your Bot
setupSteps.content:
Create a dedicated email address for OpenClaw, or use an existing one. Popular options:

  • Gmail ‚Äî enable "App Passwords" (requires 2FA enabled). Go to Google Account ‚Üí Security ‚Üí App Passwords and generate one.
  • Custom domain ‚Äî set up a mailbox like claw@yourdomain.com via your hosting provider
  • Fastmail, ProtonMail Bridge, or any IMAP provider

For Gmail, the IMAP server is imap.gmail.com and SMTP is smtp.gmail.com.

setupSteps.title: Configure OpenClaw for IMAP/SMTP
setupSteps.content:
Add the email channel to your config:

{
  "channels": {
    "email": {
      "imap": {
        "host": "imap.gmail.com",
        "port": 993,
        "user": "your-bot@gmail.com",
        "password": "YOUR_APP_PASSWORD",
        "tls": true
      },
      "smtp": {
        "host": "smtp.gmail.com",
        "port": 465,
        "user": "your-bot@gmail.com",
        "password": "YOUR_APP_PASSWORD",
        "secure": true
      },
      "pollIntervalMs": 30000,
      "allowedSenders": ["you@example.com"]
    }
  }
}

The pollIntervalMs setting controls how often OpenClaw checks for new emails (30 seconds above).

setupSteps.title: Set Up Email Filtering (Optional)
setupSteps.content:
You probably don't want OpenClaw responding to every email. Configure filters:

  • allowedSenders ‚Äî only process emails from specific addresses
  • Subject prefix ‚Äî only process emails with a specific subject prefix like [claw]
  • Label/folder filtering ‚Äî in Gmail, use a filter to label certain emails, then configure OpenClaw to only read that label

setupSteps.title: Start and Test
setupSteps.content:
Start OpenClaw:

openclaw gateway start

Send an email to your bot's address from an allowed sender. OpenClaw will read it, process it, and reply via email. Check your inbox for the response.

useCases: AI email assistant that drafts replies to common inquiries
Automated customer support via email
Email triage ‚Äî summarize, categorize, and prioritize your inbox
Scheduled email reports and digests
platformNotes:
Email is universal ‚Äî everyone has it, every business uses it. Key advantages of the OpenClaw email integration:

  • Universal reach ‚Äî works with anyone who has an email address
  • No API approval needed ‚Äî IMAP/SMTP is an open standard
  • Asynchronous ‚Äî perfect for tasks that don't need instant responses
  • Attachment support ‚Äî process PDFs, images, spreadsheets attached to emails
  • Works with any provider ‚Äî Gmail, Outlook, Fastmail, self-hosted, anything with IMAP
requirements: An email account with IMAP/SMTP access
App password or application-specific credentials
OpenClaw installed on a VPS or local machine

title: How to Connect OpenClaw to SMS: Complete Setup Guide
description: Step-by-step guide to connecting OpenClaw to SMS via Twilio. Build an AI assistant that sends and receives text messages.

setupSteps.title: Set Up a Twilio Account
setupSteps.content:
Go to twilio.com and create an account. Twilio is the most popular SMS API provider. From the console, you'll need:

  • Account SID
  • Auth Token

Purchase a phone number from the Phone Numbers section. Choose a number with SMS capability. Twilio numbers start at $1.15/month (US numbers).

setupSteps.title: Configure the Webhook
setupSteps.content:
In the Twilio Console, go to your phone number's settings and set the "When a message comes in" webhook to your OpenClaw server:

https://your-server.com/sms/webhook

Set the HTTP method to POST. This tells Twilio to forward incoming SMS messages to your OpenClaw instance.

setupSteps.title: Configure OpenClaw for Twilio SMS
setupSteps.content:
Add SMS to your OpenClaw config:

{
  "channels": {
    "sms": {
      "provider": "twilio",
      "accountSid": "YOUR_ACCOUNT_SID",
      "authToken": "YOUR_AUTH_TOKEN",
      "phoneNumber": "+1YOUR_TWILIO_NUMBER",
      "webhookPath": "/sms/webhook",
      "allowedNumbers": ["+1YOUR_PERSONAL_NUMBER"]
    }
  }
}

setupSteps.title: Start and Test
setupSteps.content:
Start OpenClaw:

openclaw gateway start

Send a text message to your Twilio number from your personal phone. OpenClaw will process the message and reply via SMS. You should see the response within a few seconds.

Cost note: Twilio charges per message ‚Äî roughly $0.0079/message for US numbers. For high-volume use, consider Twilio's committed-use discounts.

useCases: AI assistant via text message ‚Äî works on any phone, no apps needed
Appointment reminders and confirmations via SMS
Two-way customer support for users who prefer texting
Automated alerts and notifications to any phone number
platformNotes:
SMS reaches every phone on earth ‚Äî no app downloads required. Key details:

  • Universal reach ‚Äî works on smartphones and feature phones alike
  • No app required ‚Äî recipients don't need to install anything
  • Per-message cost ‚Äî Twilio charges ~$0.0079/segment for US SMS (160 characters per segment)
  • MMS support ‚Äî send and receive images and media via Twilio
  • Carrier regulations ‚Äî US carriers require A2P 10DLC registration for business texting; Twilio handles the compliance
  • Character limits ‚Äî SMS messages are limited to 160 characters per segment; longer messages are split
requirements: A Twilio account (or alternative SMS API provider)
A purchased phone number with SMS capability
OpenClaw installed on a VPS with a public HTTPS endpoint
Webhook URL accessible from the internet
